title: Facial Expression Detection using Filtered Local Binary Pattern Features with ECOC Classifiers and Platt Scaling

author: Raymond Smith, Centre for Vision, Speech and Signal Processing, University of Surrey

segmentation: Hello, my name is Ray Smith from the University of Surrey.
And I'm going to talk about some work that I've been doing on the recognition of facial expressions.
The method is based on.
The facial action coding system.

Which is an idea developed by a psychologist Ecklund whereby in the first instance facial expressions are recognized by detecting one of our number of about 40 small muscle movements such as raised eyebrow or lower eyelid.
And then these groups of muscle visa collection units and these are mapped to expressions groups from.
So this shows the architecture of such a system.
First facial images captured and then the faces detected in register and then suitable features are extracted, passed through a classifier.
To recognize individual action units and then the expression itself is determined and some appropriate action is taken depending on the application.
So I'd like to just talk about two specific problems that have arisen in this work.
The first of these concerns, the fact with the output from the classifier, gives a score for each of the known action units, and one would like to be able to separate these scores.
From when the action unit is present and when it's not present, but in practice by 10 very well separated.
So to get around this problem.
I applied the method of Platt scaling.
The idea is to fit a sigmoid curve to a training set.
And then apply the same calibration curve to new patterns.
So the calibration curve is shown on the left.
And on the right is showing the effects of applying this method.
The top histogram shows the distributions before applying Platt scaling, and you can see the distributions are heavily overlapped.
The bottom histogram shows after Plumb Platt scaling, and in this case when the action unit is present.
The points are mostly to the right hand side of the midpoint.
And when it's not present to the left hand side, so this gives a much better separation.
The second issue is what method to use for feature extraction.
Here I've shown faster two approaches.
The first is just to apply PCA.
And the second is to use method of local binary patterns, which is a feature.
Which is a texture analysis method where one can use a number of sliding windows of different sizes to generate a very large number of features, probably over 100,000.
So to get them down to something more reasonable I used a filtering method.
Unless the table shows that the LVP method tends to outperform the PCA one.
Both in terms of detection errors on the action units and increased size of area under the Roc code.
Thank you.
